div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice every Wednesday at about S.S. a.m. in time for the Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice at 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival at Trieste every Wednesday at about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reaching London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and Luggage-Van attached every Saturday to the Express Train leaving Cairo at 9.30 a.m. and will be conveyed directly to the Quay alongside the steamer.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.

Subscribed Capital £1.500,000
Reserve Fund . . £500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.

div.head: WHAT IS WHISKEY?
div.p: The decision of the London magistrate, Mr. Fordham, last week on the subject of the whisky problem is described as momentous. The following article from the "Daily Telegraph" on this epoch-making decision will therefore be read with interest. It may be as well to state at once that indignation is a mild term by which to describe the feeling excited in some quarters by the magisterial pronouncement. Needless to say, however, opinion is divided on the subject. In one direction there is something like jubilation at the result of the Islington test case. In others it would hardly be too much to say that consternation has been occasioned.

It seems, after all, that the queetion really ought to be—"When is whisky not whisky?" But, in as much as the whole problem teems with complications and technicalities — a "blend" to be avoided at all costs—a dear conception of the main issue is at least desirable. Let it be understood, then, that there are, roughly, two kinds of whisky. There is pot-still Whisky and there is patent-still whisky. The difference is beautifully simple. The first— and genuine—article is distilled from pure malt; the other is not. It may be made, apparently, from almost anything. Technically, the "whisky" which is not malt whisky is "grain," or "patent" spirit, and it may be derived from maize, or rice, or molasses, or even potatoes. The question, then, upon which Mr. Fordham had to adjudicate was whether spirits made in patent stills, with an infusion— quantity unknown—of pot-still whisky, could be legitimately sold to the public as Scotch, or Irish, whisky. And he decided in the negative. He went further, and said that such staff was not whisky at all. And, not to mince matters, be euded by calling it a "fraud."

This decision means, paradoxically enough, that a good many thousands of people who have been drinking "whisky" ever since they grew up may now plume themselves and comfort their teetotal friends—if they have any— with the reflection that they have, probably never tasted it in their lives. And the decision also means—unless it be reversed upon appeal —that in future a new name will have to be invented for the "grain" spirit, which contains only a proportion of malt whisky, and for the ''blends" which have become so popular in recent years. Someone has suggested "whiskyette." But that would be horrible. On the other hand it is hard to believe that anyone would like to be overheard asking for "special patent-still spirit." It is a difficult problem.

Meanwhile, what is the opinion in the trade? As has been said, it is divided, as was only inevitable. In order that a representative view might be obtained on the side of the blenders,Messrs. James Buchanan were approached. But at the London offices of this well-known firm nothing was to be elicited except the laconic statement that "Mr. Buchanan is away, and in his absence that matter cannot be discussed." In another quarter no less representative, the assurance was forthcoming that the decision of the North London magistrate would most certainly be contested, and that steps were already being taken for an important meeting in the trade to be held, at which a definite plan of action should be agreed to. In the meantime, this authority added, it was desirable that Mr. Fordham's decision should not be "publicly condemned."

A representative who called at Messrs. Gilbey's secured from one of the heads of that firm a complete endorsement of the magisterial view. "We have always maintained," he said, that when the public ask for whisky and get the patent-still stuff they are being imposed upon. Of course, if people prefer to drink a blended brand they are perfectly entitled to have it. But they ought, at any rate, to know exactly what they are buying, and most certainly they ought not to be made to pay as much for the one thing as for the other."

In support of this view it was explained that the difference in the price between pot-still and patent-still alcohol was as much as 2s 3d per gallon. Yet practically the same is often charged for a bottle of "blended" whisky, containing only a small proportion of pure malt, as for that which is genuine pot-still "Scotch" or "Irish." "No wonder," it was added, "enormous profits have been made by the sale, at prices charged for the more expensively produced article, of blended brands, palmed off on the public as 'Old Highland Whisky.' Between the one thing and the other there is just as much difference as exists between margarine butter and pure butter. And the public have quite as much right to be protected against the one class of brand as the other. Those who prefer margarine can always get it. But the law allows of no deception in the matter."

In other directions similar views were expressed in support of the result of the Islington proceedings. Incidentally the opinion was hazarded that far, too much laxness has prevailed in regard to the Adulteration Acts. The uninitiated will be interested to learn, on high authority, that Ireland, in the matter of its whiskies, enjoys a far purer record than does Scotland. "At no good distillery is Ireland," it was affirmed in one quarter, "is patent spirit used" ; and in Dublin, at all events —whatever may be the case in Belfast—there is probably no such thing as a patent-still." On the score of the deleteriousness of much of the so-called whisky told all over the country (London, it will be-readily believed, is felly supplied with the article), there seem to be no two opinions. But, on the other hand, nothing like unanimity, to judge from careful inquiries, exists as to whether the "blended" concoction really is injurious, as compared with pure malt whisky.

Certainly there is ample evidence that a large section of the public favours the mild "whisky" (the description henceforth must be used with caution) which is produced from a fusion of "silent" spirit and malt. But a fluid of which 90 per cent. is innocent of the latter, and is only a year old, mast, it will be generally admitted, leave a good deal to be desired. It was asserted last weak that 70 per cent of the "Scotch" whisky put upon the market consists of grain spirit. And it was further declared that the "whisky" prepared for shipment to the Colonies, in the generality of cases, was worse even than that concocted for consumption in England. This would seem to be a matter in which some form of "protection" might even meet with the approval of the present Government.

div.head: Egyptian Army.
div.p: El Bimbashi C.E. Hills, Department of Supplies, has been appointed Staff Officer Supplies, Sudan North.

div.head: Arsenal for Khartoum.
div.p: It is stated that the Egyptian Government has decided to expand a sum ot L.E. 15,000 on the establishment of an arsenal in Khartoum.

div.head: Alexandria Cab Fares.
div.p: The new tariff of fares for the hire of hackney carriages in Alexandria is published in yesterday's "Journal Official" and has now come into force.

div.head: New Tanzim Office.
div.p: A sum of L.E. 1,200 has recently been allotted by the Government for the establishment of a Tanzim Office in Cairo, instead of the office which it was formerly intended to build at Simbellawein.

div.head: Ball at Halouan.
div.p: A fancy dress ball will take place at the Grand Hotel, Helouan, on Friday next, 9th inst. A special train will leave Helouan for Cairo after the ball. It will start from Helouan at 1.15 a.m., arriving at Bab el-Look at 1.50 a.m.

div.head: Alexandria Harbour Extension.
div.p: A decree has been signed authorising the expropriation of a large quantity of land necessary for the prolongation of the Alexandria quays on the coast from Gabbari to Mex. The buildings situated on the said land will also be expropriated.

div.head: A Dishonest Servant.
div.p: A female servant employed in the house of the late Ibrahim Bev Zo El Fikar. Cairo, stole a sum of L.E. 1,200 in banknotes from her master's residence a few days ago. The woman was arrested, and the Parquet has opened enquiry.

div.head: British Club.
div.p: The formal opening of the new British Club at Alexandria will take place on Saturday, 10th inst., when the committee will receive members and their friends from 4.30 to 7.30 p.m. Ladies are especially invited. The general meeting of the members will be held at the club at 9 p. m.

div.head: The Mena House Case.
div.p: This morning the Appeal Court of the Mixed Tribunals was to have given judgment in the appeal of George Nungovich Bey against the decision of the Cairo Mixed Court of 1st Instance in the Mena Honse pre-emption case, but the delivery of the judgment was postposed until next Thursday.

div.head: Zizinia Theatre.
div.p: The great French actor M. Le Bargy, who is a societaire of the Comedie Francaise, and Mlle Marguerite Barety, from the Odeon, will arrive at Alexandria from France on Tuesday next and will appear the same evening at the Zizinla Theatre with a strong company. The repertoire contains some of the best productions of the French stage.

div.head: Ghizah Reformatory.
div.p: A very pleasant garden party was given by Mrs. Coles Pasha at the Reformatory, Ghizeb, yesterday afternoon. The reformatory boys gave a fine display of club swinging, physical drill, and gymnastics to the music of the reformatory band, which played capitally. Visits were paid to the workshops and the afternoon proved most enjoyable to the 150 odd who were present, among whom were Lord and Lady Cromer.

div.head: A. L. M. & D. S.
div.p: A most successful concert was given by the Alexandria Literary, Musical, and Dramatic Society on Saturday last at Lifonti's concert room, before a large and appreciative audience. The programme was quite up to the usual standard of the concerts given by the society and would have been difficult to improve upon, each item being received with warm approval. Piano solos were excellently rendered by Miss Mary Lopez, violin solos by Messrs. F Corbo and V Hall, and songs by Mesdames Cree and Baylis and Miss Calogeropoulo, whose splendid singing was received with enthusiasm. Messrs. Rynd and Dodwell also contributed to the programme and were very successful. The sincere thanks of all present and of the society are due to the above ladies and gentlemen, as also to those who so kindly accompanied the soloists. Several people were heard to express the hope that similar entertainments would be given again in the near future. We understand that another concert is being organised for an early date.

div.head:
KING AND KAISER.
HIS MAJESTY INTERCEDES FOR PEACE.
div.p: Today's "Petit Parisien" says that its London correspondent telegraphs that King Edward, in a personal letter to the Kaiser, has indicated the broad lines of a possible arrangement of such a nature as to make it possible for Germany to return to her former attitude without any loss of dignity. The correspondent adds that he can guarantee the reliability of the news as it emanates from a person in King Edward's entourage.

div.head: FRENCH CABINET CRISIS.
div.p: Notwithstanding the resignation of the French Cabinet, the "Times" states that M. Ronvier will continue the direction of Foreign Affairs until his successor is appointed, and therefore it is hopeful of a satistactory conclusion to the Morocco Conference.

div.head: AMERICAN STOCKS & SHARES.
div.p: NEW YORK, Monday.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive left Alexandria yesterday evening for Koubbeh Palace, and came in this morning to Abdeen Palace, where he received in audience the Ministers and Sir Vincent Corbett.

His Highness will receive Lord Cromer this afternoon. Tomorrow morning he will give audience to M. de la Bouliniere, who will present M Reffye, French Consul at Cairo; the Archduke Joseph of Austria, Sir Wm. Haynes-Smith, Dr. Wm. Bull, and Baron Rucker- Jenisch, who will bid farewell to his Highness.
At 4 p.m the Khedive will pay a visit to the Archduke Joseph at Shepheard's Hotel.
On the occasion of the departure of Baron Rucker-Jenisch the Khedive will give a banquet, in honour of the retiring German Agent, at Abdeen Palacs on Saturday.

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION.
div.p: The Coast Guard cruiser Nour el-Bahr returned to Suez yesterday from Akaba and reports that there is no change in the situation.

We may state, however, that the report published in the European Press to the effect that upwards of 6,000 Turkish troops are encamped at Tabah, is absolutely without foundation. Under ordinary conditions the water supply at Tabah would not suffice for the needs of more than a hundred at the outside. Even if new wells had been sunk by the Turks it is highly improbable that the post they have established at this point is held by more than 150 men. In fact it is considered to be unlikely that the Turks could effect a concentration of more than 5,000 in the whole district, which is notoriously waterless and produces nothing in the way of vegetation but camel thorn.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The election certificates and letters of nomination for the new members of the Municipal Commission have been sent by the Ministry of the Interior to the Gouvernorat to the handed over to the elected members.
The Gouvernorat has also received from the Ministry of the Interior the duplicate of the arrete setting forth the composition of be Municipal Commission since its partial renewal.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES.
div.p: Alert II. writes in the London "Financier" : —Egyptian Estates, Limited, completes its first financial year on March 3, but as the report will not be ready for a few weeks some information as to the company's operations which I glean from recent issues of the "Egyptian Gazette" may be of interest. One of the most important transactions was the purchase of the entire capital of the Chaba Land Company, consisting of 40,000 shares of £1 each, whereby 2,600 faddaus of agricultural land in the neighbourhood of Dossouk were acquired, together with a one sixth interest in the Boullos Land Company, in which the Delta Land Company is also interested to a similar extent. A further 2,200 feddans on the Mahmondieh Canal, at Atteh were bought from Mr. Ama bile Cumbo. The Egyptian Estates was victorions in both the cases of pre-emption brought against it in regard to the purchase of land at Siouf, and it has now entered into occupation of this property.
[The writer is wrong as to the date of the closing of the financial year, which is the 10th inst., and not the 3rd.]

div.head:
CAIRO TO CAIRO.
VIA UGANDA.
SOMETHING NEW FOR THE TOURIST.
div.p: In the latest issue of our East African contemporary "The Globe Trotter" the Editor remarks :—

The new Cairo to Cairo route via the Uganda Railway offers the blase tourist something new, novel and interesting. The diversity of scenery and the continuous exhibition of wild game can nowhere be equalled. From Mombasa to Nairobi thence to Entebbe on the great Lake Victoria Nyanza affords one a continuous panorama of the wonders of nature. From this great inland sea to Gondokoro and Khartoum, the oldest travellers will find a virgin route. I learn from Messrs. Thomas Cook and Son that the large number of enquiries have necessitated their compiling some information for intending travellers. The comforts to be had on the Uganda Railway and the palatial Lake steamers are too well known to dwell on. The journey from Entebbe to Butiabi on Lake Albert Nyanza one hundred and eighty miles distant can now be done comfortably in a ricksha. Rest-houses have been erected at a distance of ten miles apart all along the road, which is kept in good condition. Telegraph offices have been established at three stations along the line. From Butiabi, Lake Albert is crossed to Nimule, a seven days journey, in smell boats. Porters and food should be taken for the entire caravan, as neither can be obtained at Nimule. From here on to Gondokoro the rivers seldom give one much trouble and are easily crossed in canoes with the aid of a wire. Regular steamers ply between Gondokoro and Khartoum, leaving the 29th of each month and arriving at Khartoum the 10th of the following. The last steamer from Gondokoro which will provide victualling and a cook, will leave on Feb. 28th, after which date it will be necessary for one to make their own arrangements for food and also take with them a cook. From Khartoum to Wady Halfa you have the comforts the Sleeping and Dining Cars the Egyptian Railway affords, after which Assouan, Luxor and Cairo by rail or Cook's palatial Nile steamers.

div.head: BANK OF ABYSSINIA AND THE ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY.
div.p: With reference to the statement that the Bank of Abyssinia had offered to take over the payment of the coupons in arrears of the Ethiopian Railway Company in exchange for the privilege of levying a special custom duty of 10 per cent., the Paris correspondent of a financial contemporary is asked to state that there cannot be a question of coupons in arrears, but rather of the surtax on the merchandise traffic to which the Ethiopian Railway Company is entitled, and which could not be collected during the last two years, thus rendering a distribution of dividends impossible. The reported offer of the Bank of Abyssinia purports an advance of 800.000 fr., which is about equivalent to the total of the Burtax in arrears.

div.head: EGYPTO-SUDANESE AGREEMENT.
div.p: At to-day's Council of Ministers, at which the Khedive presided, the question of concluding an agreement between the Egyptian and Sudanese Governments, in regard to the pensions and rewards to be awarded to Egyptian and Sudanese employes who are or may be transferred from either Government to the other, was discussed.

div.head:
BRITISH RECREATION CLUB.
HOW TO BE HAPPY THOUGH MARRIED.
div.p: The Rev. E. J. Hardy, C.F., author of "How to be happy though married," gave a lecture on Tuesday evening at the British Recreation Club on "Marriage."

Although the subject is prehistoric, and legions have tried it with varied experience, yet the reverend gentleman, with Irish wit and amusing aneodotes, made the lecture most interesting both to the initiated and to the uninitiated.

After a brief word of sound advice to the young man as affecting the future happiness of his home, even onto the third and fourth generations, the lecturer reviewed the various stages, the wooing, the engagement, the ceremony, the honeymoon, the first quarrel, the last word, widows and widowers, and finally the parted who hoped to meet again.

Then followed an instrnmental and vocal entertainment. The programme included a piano solo by Mrs. Banani, a duet by Miss Hayes and Miss Bains, a violin solo by Mr. Trend, songs by the Rev. Thompson Burns, Mr. Willis Hayes (whose voice has improved remarkably under training), Mrs. Fanwick, and Mr. Paterson, a recitation by Mr. Knight Adken and comic songs by Mr. Sidney Collacott, Mr. Sam Ades, and Mr. Cairns.
Although much talent was shown and appreciated, yet Mr. Cairns' personality fairly brought the house down, especially with "Stop your tickling Jock" as an encore.

div.head:
AT THE SAVOY.
TUESDAY'S BALL.
LARGE & DISTINGUISHED GATHERING.
div.p: The fancy-dress ball at the Savoy on Tuesday was every whit as successful as the one given at Ghezireh the preceding week, and though a certain number of the same costumes made a second appearance there were many others which had all the charm of novelty. The evening commenced with many cheery dinner parties, the excellent ladies' band discursing much sweet music during the hour given over to the discussion of the menu. The restaurant and dining-room were hardly sufficient to accommodate the guests, many of whom appeared in the motley garb which they sustained all evening. Khairy Bey was entertaining a large party of friends at a long and beautifully decorated table in the centre of the restaurant. His guests included Prince Fouad, De Martino Pacha and Mme De Martino, Harari Pacha and Mme Herari, M. Ferdinand De Martino, Mme Aghion, M. L. Chatillon, M. and Mme R. Rolo, M. and Mme Maurice Cattaui Bey, M. and Mme Joseph Cattaui Bey, M. and Mme Gustave Cattaui, M. and Mme Adolf Cattaui, the Duke de Cirella, M. Gennaropoulo, M. and Mme Ballet, M. Andre Suares, M. and Mme Suzzate.
Hosts and Hostesses.

Mme Sursock had at her table the Comte Gabriel de Zegheb and his daughter, while at the table of M. and Mme Dumaresq were the Comte and Comtesse de Sierstorpff, Mr. and Mrs. Iddings, Mrs de Weerth, Miss Salden, the Comte Batthjany, and Mr. and Mrs. Rumbold. The Misses Pell's guests included Major Palmer, Mr. and Mrs. Storrs, Col. and Mrs. Matchett, Mr. and Mrs. Wilkinson, Capt Broadbent the Misses Coles and Mr. and Mrs. Hann. Prince Louis and Prince Antoine d'Orleans, with the Comte Chorinsky, were the guests of M. and Mme de Bitner, and at Mrs. Leveridge's table were Capt. and Mrs. Morgan, and Mr. and Mrs. Scott-Dalgleish.
Other hosts of the evening were Mr. de Vilmarin, Major Oxlev, Mr. Nisbet, Mr. Diamand, Mr. Livesay. Mr. Ward Boys, Mr. de Paravicini, Sir James Blyth, Mr. Ward, and Dr. Armstrong.

It had been announced that the fines for appearing in ordinary evening dress would be given to the fund for the employes of the hotel, and the very fair sum of about £40 has been already placed to the credit of this most excellent undertaking.
Some of the Costumes.

A great many people were puzzled over the identity of the very skittish nurse who appeared in a neat grey gown and blue tippet, with a white veil upon her auburn tresses, and it was some time before the features of Mr. Bird were recognised, in spite of his behaviour being passing strange for one of the sisterhood. Two other gentlemen had elected to appear as ladies of the harem, but the hang of their skirts, to say nothing of the garments that appeared beneath them, betrayed at once their deception. Mr. Bennett was once more seen as the Tomboy—or, as he preferred to call himself, Mellin's Baby—and it was well he had no anxious chaperone to watch over his random steps. The Mlle Zakrevaky appeared again in their beautiful and dignified costumes of the Russian Court of ancient days, and were the cynosure of all eyes. They are indeed to be envied, and are as charming as they look. Many people declared that Mrs. Wilding's costume of La Camargo was the best in the room, and certainly it would be difficult to find one better designed or more becoming to her petite figure. The tight-fitting decollete bodice of blue grey velvet was out with short full basque and worn over a very full and short white satin, trimmed with tiny festoons of velvet. The little velvet hat poised upon her powdered head was tilted forward by a mass of feathers, and a stiff narrow ruff encircled her throat Mrs. Daniell wore a wonderful Indian nautch dress, of flame coloured net and satin, a soft sash and gold ornaments swathing the hips, and a short bolero like-coatee forming the corsage. A long veil floated from her head and she wore many jewels and ornaments of barbaric splendour. There were two Carmens, Mrs Andreas and Miss Charnaud, one in scarlet skirt and sash, full white chemisette, and rose decked mantilla, and the second in yellow satin with tiny purple bolero. Miss Pepper and her sister were trim and neat in their dainty serving gowns, the one in black, the other in grey, with caps and aprons to sustain the characters, and Miss Hobson made a charming Marquerite in grey with lace cap.
Barbario Splendour.

For real barbaric splendour the palm must be awarded to Mr. Jennings, who looked twice as large as life in his magnificent garments of ancient Egypt. The short double skirt or kilt was of brilliant shades of blue and green striped with gold, and above the waist was a many-coloured broad belt with the scarab and ibis wing design so often appearing in Egyptian art. Wide semi-circular plaques of gold hung round his neck, and a bead anklet and chains added further touches of colour, and his helmet-shaped cap was striped with blue and white. Lieut. Cunningham was again resplendent in his character of Knave of Diamonds, though why he chose the diamond in place of better things, it would be hard to guess. The troupe of Anglo-Americans made one ache to ask the reason for its thusness : for its variegated uniform surely was of Manchester manufacture for the Indian market, and its headgear was a riddle in itself. Dr. Madden as Mrs. Jarley was much admired, and the same remark might also be applied to the shadow of Napoleon as he paced in solemn stateliness among the light-hearted crowd. The following list includes as many of the names and costumes as it was possible to procure :—

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir Horace Pinching returned to Cairo yesterday from his inspection in Upper Egypt.
The late Middlemass Bey died at Drayton Gardens, South Kensington, after only a week's illness.

The marriage took place at Bingham-Melcombe, Dorset, last week, of Professor Goldmann, of the University of Freiburg Baden, and Miss Lorna Bosworth Smith, daughter of Mr. Bosworth Smith, formerly of Harrow School. The Rev. H. P. Cronshaw, Vicar of St. Stephen's, Westbourne Park, was best man, and the service was conducted by the Rev. F. Noel Smith, of the Marlborough Mission, Tottenham, assisted by Prebendary Wickham, uncle of the bride. Professor and Mrs. Goldmann afterwards left for Egypt and Greece.

Dr. Horton, who has been President of the National Free Church Council during the past year, and Mr. Joseph King, the Liberal candidate in the Thanet division, are leaving London for a tour in Palestine.

The following passengers travelled to Upper Egypt by the train de luxe on Tuesday :— Mr. J. V. Vickers, Mr. E. S. Luad, Mrs. Grahame, Miss Mosley, Baron Lederer and party of 3, Mr. Mather and party of 3, Tawfik Nabla. Mr Gayes, Mr. Vial, Mr. Giraud, Miss Fitzroy Kelly, Mr. Nessim Grain.

There will be ordinary polo afterwards.

div.head: FOOTBALL.
div.p: A correspondent favours us with the following interesting description of a match at Ras el-Tin :––On the afternoon of Sunday last, a football match was played by the Customs Athletic Club and Rasel-Tin Government School on the latter's ground. The game was witnessed by the professors of the school, the majority of the scholars, and great number of Customs officials.

Play began at 4.30 p.m. It was, however, carried on in such a way that it is beyond our power to express the credit due to Mr. Clarke Shaw, the tutor of athletic games in the school, who was acting as a referee, and who jastly decided disputes. The spectators were much struck by the gentle maneuvres practised by both sides. The goal-keeper of the Customs team was decidedly a splendid player who manfully defended his post. The forwards of the school were such gallant players, that thay were unceasingly rushing and attacking their opponents, that their way of discharging their duties was highly applauded by the lookers on. The result was that Ras el-Tin beat the Customs three to one. The two parties then exchanged thanks for the sympathies and gentle methods of play exercised by both towards one another. The Customs players, accompanied by their play-rivals, were at last led to a floor of the school where they all were served with tea.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal arrived at Marseilles yesterday morning from Alexandria.
The Papayanni liner City of Perth left Malta last evening and is due here on Sunday next.
The Moss liner Rameses sailed yesterday afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, in including 4,872 bales cotton and 3,660 bags onions.
The S.S. Creole Prince from Manchester left. Malta yesterday and is due at Alexandria on Sunday.
The S.S. Kaffir Prince, left Antwerp yesterday, and is due at Alexandria via Smyrna on or about March 28.

div.head:
FRENCH CABINET CRISIS.
CAUSED BY SEPARATION LAW.

div.p: The Chamber has rejected by 267 votes against 234 an order of the day approving the declarations of the Government on the subject of the application of the law for the separation of the churches from the State.
M. Rouvier stated that the Government wonld not take any part in the continuance of the debate and left the House, followed by the other Ministers. (Havas)
M. Fallieres has accepted the resignation of the Cabinet.
The majority of 267 votes included the whole of the Right, half of the Progressives, with M. Ribot, most of the Socialists, and a number of Radical Socialists.

The crisis was brought on by an interpellation of M. Plichon on the subject of the inventory of the Boeschepe church, during which the demonstrators seriously injured the collector, whose son shot one of the demonstrators dead.
M. Rouvier had stated that he would apply the law with moderation. (Havas)

CHAMBER OF DEPUTIES.—During the discussion on the Naval Estimates M. Lockroy was cheered for his speech declaring that the naval programme was inadequate and pointing out the importance of the navy in the event of war with Germany. (Reuter)
The Moorish officials state that they are indifferent as to the conclusions arrived at by the delegates as they do not intend to accept any clauses of which they disapprove. (Reuter)
The Budget Committee of the Reichstag has passed the first installment for the construction 61 two torpedo divisions and £2,600,000 marks for submarines. (Reuter)

HOUSE OF COMMONS.—During the discussion on the Naval Estimates, Mr. Robertson said that only three cruisers would be laid down this year instead of four, as proposed in last year's programme. (Reuter)
Mr. Haldane announced in the House that flogging in the army would henceforth be totally abolished. (Reuter)
The imports during February amounted to £17,500,000 and the exports to £28,750,000, showing an increase of £4,700,000 and £3,500,000 respectively. (Reuter)
Thirty artillery men have been sentenced to long terms of imprisonment for refusing to work their guns against the rioters. (Reuter)
The chief of police has been dismissed owing to the continuance of daylight murders and armed raids on banks and offices. (Reuter)
The Cabinet has resigned owing to its inability to accept Austria's proposals for commercial arrangements. (Reuter)
The preliminary rites in connection with Princess Ena's conversion were performed here yesterday. The Pope sent Princess Ena rich presents and an autograph letter. (Reuter)

The conversion of Princess Ena took place this morning in the Chapel of the Miramar Palace in the presence of the Spanish Royal Family and the Premier. Bishop Brindle received the adjuration. Queen Christina acted as Godmother and Prince Ferdinand of Bavaria as Godfather. Kind Edward was not present. (Reuter)
King Edward has arrived here. (Reuter)

div.head: POLITICAL PARABLES.
div.p: During the greater part of last year the pages of the "Westminster Gazette" were enlivened once a week by a political parable by the "Office Boy" (Mr. Francis Brown). The exceeding cleverness of these skits on the late Government lies in their pungent ingenuousness. The illustrations of the text are delightful and fall little short of Mr. Gould's political caricatures. The parables have been collected in a single volume, which have just been published by Mr. T. Fisher Unwin. (1s. net). The volume forms most amusing reading and the moral conveyed is as fresh as ever in view of the result of the recent general election.

Another of Mr. Unwin's recent publications is Mr. Charles Wagner's eloquent appeal to young men, entitled "Toward the Heights." A more suitable gift for a youth or young man could not be found, for in spite of the intense moral earnestness of the contents, it is most interesting. The book is published in a convenient size and at a very moderate price (1s. paper, 2s. cloth, net).

div.head: Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ltd.
div.p: SOCIETE DES ENTREPOTS D'ALEXANDRIE.
AVIS

Messieurs les actionnaires de l'Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Company Limited sont convoques en Assembles Generale ordinaire pour le vendredi 16 Mars 1906 dans les bureaux de MM. Carver Brothers Co. Ltd. a 3 heures et demie de relevee.
Pour faire partie de l'Assembles Generale il faut etre proprietaire de dix actions an moins et le depot devra etre effectue le 14 Mars au plus tard chez MM. Carver Brothers Co. Limited.
Tout actionnaire peut se faire representer par d'autres actionnaires faisant partie de l'Assemblee Generale moyennant depot d'un pouvoir ecrit regulier.
ORDRE DU JOUR :
1 Lecture du rapport du Conseil d'Administration ;
2 Lecture du rapport du Commissaire de surveillance.
3 Approbation des comptes de l'exercice 1905 s'il y a lieu ;
4 Fixation du dividende a distribuer ;
5 Nomination d'administrateurs ;
6 Nomination du commissaire de surveillance.
Le President
S. H. CARVER
Alexandrie, le 28 Fevrier 1906. 27395-2-2

div.head: African World and Cape-Cairo Express, London.
div.p: Mr. A. Imrie Shadden, special representative of the above journal, is at present in Cairo and all business communications should be addressed to him c/o the National Bank of Egypt, when they will be promptly attended to.

div.head: Agricultural Bank of Egypt.
div.p: The Director of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt beg to inform the shareholders that at the Ordinary General Meeting held in Cairo om 28th February, 1906, the following distribution was decided upon :—
I. A dividend of £ 0 7/6 per Share to the Ordinary Shares of the first issue against delivery of coupon No. 3.
II. A dividend of £ 15:15/- per Share to the Deferred Shares against delivery of coupon No. 2.
The coupons are payable at the Offices of the National Bank ol Egypt, Cairo, Alexandria and London.

ASTLEY P. FRIEND.

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIA
div.p: AVIS
La Municipalite met en adjudication les travaux de construction de la toiture de l'atelier des Ecuries Municipales de Chatby.
Le cautionnement est fixe a L.E. 20 (Vingt):
Le cahier des charges est depose au Bureau Technique ou il peut etre consulte par les interesses tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours feries exceptes.
Les offres devront etre adressees sous pli cachete a Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalite avant le 13 mars courant.
Elles pourront egalement etre deposees en seance de la Delegation le meme jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour construction de la toiture de l'atelier des Eouries Municipales de Chatby."

Le cautionnement on le recu d'une banque, d'apres les conditions du cahier des charges, devra etre remis separement au Service de la Comptabilite Generale avant l'onverture des offres et au plus tard le 13 mars courant 4 midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditious ci-dessus sera acartee.
L'Administrateur,
(Signe) W.P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 6 Mars 1906. 27443-3-1

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien.
div.p: AVIS

Faisant suite au precedent avis concernant le pont de Dessouk, l'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat a 1'honneur de faire savoir au public que les ouvertures normales de ce pont a la navigation ont ete reprises depuis le 27 Fevrier dernier.
Le Caire, le 5 Mars 1906. 27445-1
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer et des Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de faire savoir au Public qu'a partir du 7 Mars courant l'horraire d'ouverture du bureau telegraphique de Kafr-Ammar sera comme suit:
de 8 h. a.m. a 1 h. p.m.
et de 3 h. p.m. a 8 h. p.m.
Le Caire, le 5 Mars 1906. 27444-1
AVIS

L'Administration a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public qu'elle recevra jusqu'an 22 Mars 1906 a midi des offres pour la fourniture de 1000 poteaux en hetre 16' x 6" x 6" et 2000 poteaux en hetre 16' x 5" x 5" selon les conditions dont on peut obtenir copie aux Magasins de Roulac et de Gabbary contre paiement de 100 milliemes.
Les offres devront etre accompagnees d'une feuille de papier timbre de 30 milliemes. Elles seront adressees par la poste sous pli recommande a : —
Monsieur le Chef du Service des Magasins, Chemins de fer de l'Etat.
Boulac (Saptieh).
et sous double enveloppe, 1'interieure portant la suscription suivante :––
"Offre pour poteaux."
L'Administration ne s'engage pas a accepter l'offre la plus basse, ni a donner suite aux sou-missions presentees, et elle se reserve le droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 5 Mars 1906.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: The weather yesterday was fine, the night being cool and windy though the sea became calm. The morning opens bright and cheerful, with a light breeze from the N.W. and a steady barometer, with prospects of continued fine weather.

div.head: The Money Market.
div.p: Is the end of the stringency at last in sight? This is the question at present engaging the attention of the money market, the influx of gold into the Bank throughout the week having rendered that event possible. The precious metal has been flowing in from many quarters, and the aim received by the Bank since our last amounts on balance to over a million and a half. The "expectation of ease" has not yet had any pronounced effect upon the loan market, owing no doubt to the requirements in connection with the Consols settlement and the heavy repayments to the Bank of England, and the rate remains practically as 4%. There is, however, just a faint glimmer of possible ease to be found even in this market, as evidenced in the patchiness of the rate today, loans in some few instances having been done at 3 3/4.

The discount market on the other hand has been working on anticipation during the past week, the rate for three months' bills having fallen at one time to 3 1/2%, but it has now hardened up to 3 5/8, being however, still abont 1/4% easier than this time last week.

For many reasons it is to be hoped that rates will not be allowed to slip away too rapidly, viz, dear money in Germany and America, the number of English bills held on the Continent (with the consequent power to withdraw gold) and last, but not least, the appearance of Japan as a buyer of bullion, at a time when this market's indebtedness to her stands at a very high figure.

The Bank's statement this week shows a fall in the proportion of reserve of 1.5 per cent, owing to the addition to the other deposits of abont three millions, and to public deposits of about £1.500,000, making this figure now stand at £18,000,000. No doubt the Government will disburse a considerable proportion of this last-mentioned sum during the present month, thereby bringing some of the much desired ease to the money market.

div.head: The Stock Markets.
div.p: The feeling in the City has been gradually less and less confident as the true intentions of the Government have become clearer. At the time of the election it was understood that both the foreign and Colonial policy of their predecessors would be continued, and in view of this understanding many moderate men freely voted for the Liberals. It now appears clear that the policy of impractical sentimen talism, which has been so fatal in the Liberal administration in the past, is still the leading principle of the party, and the lessons of days gone by, which have been so costly to the country, are being entirely ignored. That a man of the calibre of Mr. Winston Churchill should have the fortunes of the country largely in his hands is enough in itself to create the greatest uneasiness in financial circles. This, in addition to the extraordinary mood of Germany, has been enough to keep everything on the Stock Exchange more than dull. Millions are being lost every day in the mining industry towards which the present Government seems to have a peculiar antipathy, and it is feared that heavy failures may result. Fortunately the markets are in a thoroughly sound condition. There has been no over-speculation ; the banks and the public have been particularly cautious, and there is no whisper of any real trouble outside the unfortunate Kaffirs, some of which have reached a point at which the future profit mast be very large if the mines are worked at all.

div.head: Gilt-Edged Securities.
div.p: The settlement in Consols was effected this week, the rate being 4 1/4%, compared with similar rate a month ago. The making-up price was 90 1/4 an advance of 3/8 during the account. The large influx of bullion has had a good influence on the gilt edged market gene rally, and on "Wednesday Consols want up to 91. They close tonight at 90 3/16 xd. for cash and 90 1/2 xd. for the new account.

div.head: Foreign Bonds.
div.p: A very dull tone has been prevalent in the market for international bonds, the price of both Japanese and Russians being below last week's level, the latter shedding 1 1/4 points in one day. The closing quotation for Russian Fours is 83 3/4.

div.head: Home Rails.
div.p: The lifeless tone which was characteristic of the home railway section throughout last week, was again present at the beginning of this week, and a considerable amount of liquidation took place. On the publication of a further batch of good traffic returns, however, these stocks received renewed attention, and some substantial buying followed. Today the market has again displayed weakness. Were is not the case that dullness is prevalent in every part of the "House," it would be difficult to account for the persistent disregard of the prospects of home railway shares. This week five of the leading lines record very substantial increases in traffic, the North Western to the extent of £10,000, as compared with a decrease in the corresponding week last year of £2,000, and the Midland of £7,674, as against a reduction in 1905 of £292. For the eight weeks to date the L. and N.W. has an increase of over £60,000, and the North Eastern and Midland follow this up with increases of £55,000 and £46,000 respectively. The Great Western's previously recorded decrease has been cleared off with this week's again of £4,300, which comes on the top of a gain last year of £2,300.

div.head: Americans.
div.p: The feeling of weakness is still prodominant in the American market. The only movement today has been in Union Pacifics, which have advanced one point. The iron markets have shown a distinct weakness, and altogether the trade reports from Arnerica are not so good as has recently been the case. The show-up of the enormous loss of over five-and-a-half million dollars on the Morgan Shipping Syndicate has created great interest. It marks tha venture as one of the greatest fiascoes of modern times.
The dosing prices in the leading American shares are as follows : —

div.head: Egyptians.
div.p: The lower-priced shares in the Egpytian market have again been in good demand, but they close easier all-round, probably in sympathy with Kaffirs, in which section heavy liquidation is going on Land General Trust advanced, but close down again at about par. Khedivial Mail have kept firm, and are still being picked up at 1 7/8. There is yet no mention of the preference shares. Delta Land have been largely dealt in up to 3 3/8, closing also easier at 3 1/4. Delta Light Railway preference had a very share move up to 12 1/2 buyers, with very few shares changing hands, but they could not maintain this rise, and close at 12 3/8 doubtful. National Bank of Egypt at 27 3/4 and Agricultural Banks at 9 15/16 are quite unmentioned. Daira Ordinary are a little better at 18, and the Deferred at 105 nominal. Daira Sugar are unchanged at 4 15/16. Abyssinian Banks have been up to 1 premium on hears buying back, but close at only 3/8 premium. There was a backwardation of 3s. per share at the carry-over, but this soon ran off to evens. Union Fonciere at 6 1/2, Corporation of Western Egypt at ¾ premium and Egyptian Estates at 1 7/8 are firm. The Estates Deferred are quoted nominally at 8––9. There is a general complaint that the Stock Exchange cannot get enongh Egyptian Estates shares. There would be a very large demand were there any stock but few shares being in the market, it is hardly worth the dealers' trouble to push business. No doubt these shares are very properly held in Egypt, but for the sake of the future it would be a good thing if enough were held here to satisfy the market.
The dividend on these is anxiously looked forward to, and it is expected that it will cause substantial rise as soon as the rumours of the excellent results of this company are verified.

div.head: Mining.
div.p: Liquidation in the South African market continues to an extraordinary degree, and prices all round are in consequence very considerably lower. Yesterday Rand Mines were down to 5 19/32 sellers, which is 1 5/32 less than the price at the end-February making-up. Goldfields were 4 15/32 sellers as against 5 5/16 at the last carry-over. Today Rand Mines close at 5 13/16 and Bast Rands at 4 3/8.

The Egyptian mining market still shares the general depression. Nile Valley have lost another shilling on the week at 5s., while United Africans and Un Rus have shed 1/4 and 1/8 respectively. The report of the Egyptian and Sudan Mining Syndicate, although considered very good, does not seem to have had any effect upon shares, but this is natural, as all mining shares are disregarded for the moment.
The closing prices tonight are as follows :––

div.head: EGYPTIAN TRADE. AMERICAN CONSULAR REPORT.
div.p: Mr. Morgan, of the American Diplomatic Agency and Consulate General at Cairo, has sent a long report to Washington about Egyptian trade. He furnishes a great many valuable facts regarding the present state of trade, suggestions of how best to enter Egypt's markets, and how to remain there once a foothold has been obtained. He writes :
Local conditions must be reckoned with.

The important fact should not be overlooked that local conditions must be conformed to, particularly that of credit. This is the rock upon which all attempts to extend American trade interests in Egypt has split. Credit—sometimes very long credit—must be given, until the ingathering of the various crops. "After I have sold my cotton," is the invariable reply of the large landowners when applied to for payment, and even the government gives credit for the taxes due, collecting them by installments after the crops have been gathered. It is as well to remember that the follish, as soon as he has made a little money at once invests it in land—he does not bank or speculate with it. He then requires seed, cattle, and machinery to develop his land, so obtains what he requires on credit and pays whan his crop is disposed of. It is not many years since all accounts were settled once a year at the Tantah fair, at which the produce of the country was disposed of. Allowed a reasonable credit by American manufacturers, as credit must be given here, there is no question that such a distributing agency as has been suggested would enormously develop American trade interests in Egypt.
Distributing Agencies Needed.

It would be in the interests of manufacturers and buyers alike to have the distributing agencies handle the goofs of competing firms. The system might not work in other countries, but it would work well in this land of paradoxes and contradictions. From inquiries I have made it is abundantly evident that "sole" or "exclusive" agencies are not always an unmixed blessing to the possessor of them, and not always to the advantage of the manufacturer granting such; but "sole agency" in the sense in which it is taken is quite a misnomer. Neither the manufacturer nor the sole agent here can prevent anyone purchasing goods in the country of origin and bringing them into Egypt through whatever channel they choose. Egypt was for years the happy hunting ground of the monopolist, and the population suffered. It has not forgotten those days ; it resents them bitterly, and when it sees "sole agent", displayed it reads "monopoly," arid if a similar artiole can be obtained elsewhere, the residents, European and Egyptian alike, will go there for it, One of my informants did not wish to place an order with the "sole agent" of a mannfacturing firm. He preferred to send the order to the firm. They replied that they could only execute it through their local representative. Neither got it; it want elsewhere. It would have been a very simple matter to fill the order and make some arrangement with the sole agent for a modified commission when orders were sent direct.
Importing Houses not Limited to Specialities.

Importing houses do not as a rule confine themselves to one specialty ; some deal in dozens, others in hundreds, and nearly all I must break bulk and become retailers in the accepted sense of the term. It goes without saying therefore, that they should be prepared to satisfy the whims and fancies of their customers for any particular brand, mark, or fabric, but if the sole agency can not sell that particular article, being bound down to deal in another brand or mark, the customer goes where he can buy what he wants, and of course takes his custom for other articles with him.

There are better opportunities for opening up new connections when you can offer client a choice of similar goods. He knows then that you are not trying to force upon him one particular article simply became you have a local monopoly in it, and are debarred from trading in a similar article produced by other firms with whom yon may not trade. Sole agencies have their uses, if the foreign manufacturer knows how to use them to his advantage, but they have their disadvantages for the manufacturer also. But this is a subject for the trade expert to determine, for no general rule could be laid down. Where a "sole agency" might work satisfactorily in one direction it might be just the reverse in another, so that cases would have to be decided upon their individual merits.
"A good article recommends itself."
HOWIE'S Butter is no exception
Awarded Twelve 1st Prize Medals at the Khedivial Agricultural Show 1902, 1903 and 1905.

div.head: SUCRERIES ET RAFFINERIE D'EGYPTE
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur del' "Egyptian Gazette."

Les quelques economies que j'avais amassees au cours de 15 annees de travail et au prix de sacrifices iuouis, economies que j'avais malheuheureusement placees en actions Sucreries, attire par le tort dividende que distribuait cette societe, viennent de recevoir, avec la decision du tribunal du Caire, leur dernier coup, le coup fatal.

Je m'entends fort pen aux questions de Loi, avec laquelle Dieu merci je n'ai jamais en rien a faire. J'avoue cependant ne rien comprendre a la facon dont la Justice est pratiquee ici, tant elle semble defier le bon sens.

Des actions qui, avant le Krach valaient fr. 170, degringolent apres a fr. 40. Tons les actionnaires sont terrasses ; Cronier se tue et le monde entier fremit devant ce scandale effroyable. Intervient la Justice. Un sentiment de soulagement gague les victimes. Mais quel n'eit pas leur etonnement de se voir ruinees "completement" par celle-la meme qui intervenait au nom de la Morale pour les defendre, car la faillite c'est 0 pour nos actions et 15% au maximum pour les creanciers et les obligataires.

Or, je me le demande, pourquoi vouloir aneantir d'un trait de plume notre entreprise, alors que tout le monde, le Gouvernement compris, fait tout son possible pour la relever et la reorganiser? Pourquoi vouloir amasser de nouvelles ruines sur celles deja existantes?

Car, l'effet d'une declaration de faillite serait plus desastreux encore que le Krach Cronier lui-meme. Elle serait une calamite pour le pays et vouerait a une ruine complete les malheueux, comme moi, qui y avaient engages avec toute leur fortune.

La mission de la Justice, telle que je, serait de defendre les faibles, de er les torts des victimes et de sauver le qui leur reste, au lieu de consommer leur ruine. Qu'on poursuive les administrateurs, mais qu'on ne nous confonde pas avec eux—et surtout qu'on nenous fasse pas payer les pots casses. Pour atteindre les administrateurs il n'est pas necessaire, ni juste de nous frapper. Precipiter dans le gouffre l'edifice sifortement ebranle par le krach est un crime, aux yeux de tous, aussi grand que celni commis par ceux a qui nous avions confie la gestion de nos affaires.
Au point de vue moral je ne puis done qu'accuser de complicite la justice dans la perte da ma fortune.
Elle aura continue et acheve l'oeavre de destruction qu'avaient ai bien commencee nos fideles administrateurs :
UN ACTIONNAIRE. A.K.

div.head: LE "QUORUM" ET LE CONCORDAT
div.p: La raison principale pour laquelle le Tribunal Mixte du Caire a refuse de tenir compte des actionnaires des Sucreries dans la recherche de la bonne ou de la mauvaise foi necessaire pour l'homologation du concordat, c'est qu'il ne constituaient pas, a son avis, "un element actif dans l'organisation sociale."

Ce role passif, que leur prete le Tribunal et qui leur coute a 1'heure actuelle pres de 32 millions 1/2 de frs. "constituerait" pourtant, nous semble-t-il, une raison suffisante pour prouver amplement la bonne foi de ces actionnaires qui representent la societe.

Pour attester leur indifference le jugement cite les quorums faibles atteints dans les Assemblees Generales et en arrive a parler de l' "abdication de la part des actionnaires" dans les mains du Conseil d'Administration.

Pour une societe qui a les 11/12 de ses actions placees a l'Etranger il n'y a pas lieu de s'etonner si ce quorum est faible. D'ailleurs le quorum attaint ordinairement dans les Assemblees de societes, dont le capital est presque entierement place dans le pays, n'est guere plus important Ainsi, pour ne citar que la National, 1'Agricultural Bank, la Salt and Soda, etc., nous dirons que le quorum n'est generalement pas atteint. Les decisions ne sont prises qu'a la seconde convocation, quel que soit alors le nombre d'actionnaires presents.
Faut-il eu conclure que ces derniers abdiquentleurs droits aux millions de Livres Sterling dont se compose le capital de ces Societes?
Nous ne le pensons pas.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujoura hui a midi et demes)
La cote a partiellement flechi sous le poids des realisations.
La Khedivial Mail, apres avoir atteint 47/6 est tombe graduellement jurqu'a 42/9 en cloture.
Plusieurs executions s'effectuent, ce qui, avec l'empressement des vendeurs, n'est pas fait pour maintenir les cours.
Aussi plusieurs valeurs ont-elles baisse a un prix tres avantageux pour ceux qui voudraient les mettre en portefeuille. De ce nombre sont la Delta Light et l'Agricole.
En revanche la Nungovich est pousse a 16 7/16 et les Egyptian Constructions a 3/4-13/16 de prime, par suite de l'egorgement des vendeurs a decouvert.
On a traite beaucoup les Estates et la New Egyptian.

En somme les valeurs lourdes sont delaissees au profit des nouvelles emissions. La reaction actuelle est une consequence de l'imprudence de certains speculateurs. C'est une epuration necessaire apres laquelle une reprise est inevitable en faveur des titres serieux.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: A Londres, le Consolide anglais est reste invarie a 90 3/8 et l'Unifiee a 105 1/4. La National Bank et l'Agricole sont renseigniees en reaction de 1/8 a 27 1/2 et 10 1/8. La Daira Sanieh a cloture en hausse de 1/8 a 17 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptien a regagne 1 franc a 791. La Banque d'Athenes est egalement en reprise de 1 franc a 147.
Notre marche des valeurs a ete, ce matin encore, tres actif, avec fort bonne tendance sur divers titres.

La National Bank s'est raffermie a 27 1/2 l'action ancienne et 26 5/8 la nouvelle. Par contre, l'Agricole est revenue a 10 1/16 l'action ancienne et 9 5/8 la nouvelle. La Banque d'Athenes s'est maintenue a 146.
L'action Credit Foncier est restee a 791; les obligations a lots 1886 ont gagne 2 francs a 340.
La Delta Light a perdu 1/16 a 12 5/16. L'Agricole du Nil a cloture a 280. La part de fondateur Enterprise and Development a atteint L.E. 17.
Tres bon mouvement sur les actions Societe d'Entreprises Immobilieres et de Travaux, qui ont avance a 4 1/4—5/16. De plus en plus recherchies, les parts de fondateur ont hausse a 10 1/2 acheteurs.
L'action ordinaire Khedivial Mail est montee a 48 sh.

Dans le groupe des Hotels, nouveau mouvement a la hausse sur les Nungovich, qui ont ete pousses jusqu'a 16 3/4 pour cloturer a 16 1/4. De leur cote, les Baehler ont hausse jusqu'a 6 3/8 pour finir a 6 1/8. Les Upper Egypt ont fait 5 3/4 et les Anglo-American 6 5/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les Estates se sont inscrits, en bonne tendance, a £2; la part de fondateur a 9 11/16. A noter egalement on mouvement sur les New Egyptian qui, de 31, ont passi a 33 sh. 6. Les Salt and Soda sont revenus a 25 sh.; les Cotton Mills ont fait 6 sh. 6 et les Markets 23 sh. 3 acheteurs. Les Egyptian Constructions ont cloture entre 1 5/8 et 1 11/16.

Pour faire suite a notre entrefilet du 1er du courant sur la Compagnie Immobiliere d'Egypte, nous pouvons ajouter aujourd'hui que l'une des operations les plus fractueuses a l'actif de cette Societe a ete la vente de l'immeuble de l'ancienne Zaptieh, realisee, au cours de l'exercice dernier, au prix de L.E. 70,000, soit avec une plus-value de plus de 100 pour cent.

D'apres ce qu'on annouce d'Alexandria, le mouvement de hausse qui s'est produit sur les actions Anglo-Egyptian Spinning and Weaving est attribue a la nouvelle que cette Societe a vendu a M.A. Luzzato un terrain a raison de P.E. 53 le pic, realisant sinsi une somme de £. 20.000.
Nous detachons d'une de nos Iettres d'AIexandrie le passage suivant:

"Les actionnaires de la Port-Said Salt Association protestent, paralt-il, contre la fusion projetee avec la Salt and Soda, moyennant echange de deux actions de la premiere Societe contre une de la seconde. Ils se basent sur plusieurs raisons, dont voici les principales :

"L'abolition du monopole donne droit a la Port-Said de vendre le sel dans le pays aux memes conditions que celles etablies pour les salines du Mex, exploitees actuellement par la Salt and Soda. Or, la concession de la Port Said a une duree de 45 aus, tandis que l'Etat pourrait modifier ou annuler apres 12 ans le contrat actuel avec la Salt and Soda.

"Le capital actuel de la Port-Said Salt, soit £80,000, est represente par un actif reel, sans compter la valeur commercials de l'affaire pour la longue dures de la concession. Par suite, les actionnaires estiment qu'avec un petit benefice sur la vente la Port-Said pourrait largement retribuer son capital.
"Ils demandent donc que les negociations actuelles scient suspendues, sauf a les repreudre sur des bases nouvelles dans la vue d'eliminer toute concurrence entre les deux Societes."
Les cours du coton sont arrives en hausse d'Amerique. Hier, le disponsible a gagne 10 points, le Mai 13 et l'Octobre 8.
Les arrivages ont ete de 33,00 balles contre 50,000.
Le marche de Liverpool est egalement en petite reprise.
Ici, le Mars, qui a fini hier soir a 19 11/16 a ouvert ce matia a 19 9/16 pour cloturer a 19 23/32.

MM. H. de Vries et Boutiguy, agents de change, se chargent de l'execution de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marches de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et New-York. La Circulaire quotidienue de la maison est envoyee sur demande.

div.head: THEATRE ZIZINIA.
div.p: Mardi soir a eu lieu le concert donne par les celebres virtuoses Mr. et Mlle Kazantzi.
La colonie grecque, qui avait tenu a feter comme il convenait ces deux admirables artistes, y avait accouru tres nombreuse.
Parmi les nombreux morceaux executes par A. Katzantzi nous signalerons le Caprice de Paganini, le Zigennerveisen de Sarasate, la Polonaise de Wieniauski et les airs Hongrois de Ernst.
Mlle Kazantzi s'est distinguee dans le St. Francois de Litzt et le Scherzo de Robinstein.
Nous esperons que ce concert ne sera pas le dernier.

div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These express steamer's have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.
